title: Replace LLL/Solidity source code with Yul

labels.name: retesteth
labels.description: Issues that are changes to retesteth, not the tests (I can't transfer there)

body:
Benefit:
- lower level code than LLL/Solidity, but still more readable than LLL
- as a result it should be more easy to audit
I suggest to keep lllc support and implement julia as an option

What is the main benefit having LLL and Solidity?

Apart from the potential that it has less bugs than Julia, but the main point of Julia is to be small and auditable and the output easily verifiable (when compared to the other two).
It is not about the benefits. It is about that we already have a lot of tests in LLL
It still can be a goal to eventually replace those old ones.
I find a subset of LLL much more intuitive than Julia or any language with variables. I don't like lllc because writing a compiler in C++ sounds weird.

One doesn't need to use variables are higher level features of Julia (or not even Julia, just plain Solidity assembly).

The main reason compared to a new language for Solidity assembly/Julia is that a compiler exists for it.

FTR (from https://github.com/ethereum/solidity/issues/1230#issuecomment-559116361):

> From call: @axic is working on standardizing some assembler language for tests, and after that remove LLL.
Is yul a good option now?
Depends. Yul doesn't give you access to some low-level opcodes (e.g `JUMP`, `PC`) but provides other constructors to achieve them (such as functions).
added solidity support. as I understand solc has yul parser ?

> Depends. Yul doesn't give you access to some low-level opcodes (e.g `JUMP`, `PC`) but provides other constructors to achieve them (such as functions).

Neither does LLL. In those cases we just write `code: :raw 0x<whatever>` and put the assembler version in comments.
actually if YUL is supported by solc  then it is already implemented

You do not need to use inline assembly to access Yul in the compiler. I'm not sure what you are using, the CLI or standard json, but there are options to invoke the assembler and pass Yul code directly.
(Julia was renamed Yul years ago. Changed title to reflect that.)

> You do not need to use inline assembly to access Yul in the compiler. I'm not sure what you are using, the CLI or standard json, but there are options to invoke the assembler and pass Yul code directly.

We use solc.

I vote we add Yul support. The reason is LLL is no longer updated, and eventually we'll have new opcodes. It isn't a problem with EIP 2315 (https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-2315) because flow control isn't something we test in lll anyway, we test it in machine language. But when a new calculation opcode comes around we'll want Yul. Might as well get used to it already.
BTW, this is a retesteth issue really. Shall I open an issue there?

![Screenshot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20340/112179121-4de2fc80-8bf2-11eb-8283-b76efe7b3fcd.png)

You can also click on `transfer issue` if you think it belongs there, but I think it actually belongs to both, as the testing format may require a change, such as a language field?

> You can also click on `transfer issue` if you think it belongs there, but I think it actually belongs to both, as the testing format may require a change, such as a language field?

I don't think we need a breaking change, any more than we needed one for Solidity (https://ethereum-tests.readthedocs.io/en/latest/state-transition-tutorial.html#solidity-tests). We might want to do something like:

```
ccc...ccccc:
        nonce: 1
        code: |
            :yul
             <Yul code goes here>
        storage: {}
```


With LLL code it always looks like this:
```
ccc...ccccc:
        nonce: 1
        code: |
            {
                 <LLL code goes here, {} are required even if it is just one command>
            }
        storage: {}
```
A yul would actually be a downside as we don't know how to add new opcode to it.

> A yul would actually be a downside as we don't know how to add new opcode to it.

1. Do you know how to add opcodes to LLL?
2. Yul is still in active development, so I assume we won't have to add opcodes to it.
Yes. We have custom repo of solidity whete we add any required opcode to lll.

added YUL support: 

https://github.com/ethereum/tests/pull/819/commits/dd6b122dddf07f5f0372bd3a7935da0f106a6665#diff-b66d7b0a699eddd78aaf5f8b2d9e35ee24b71aa255f14d7c6d3f80a37ff7d9e8R34
